"Republicans are determined to protect millionaires and defense contractors, no matter the costs to the country."

In a civilized and democratic country, it is hard to believe that this style of 'governing' is still happening. Defense and military spending has approximately doubled since 2001, and with Republicans, apparently no amount is too much for that sacred cow. Apparently some who watched the movie Wall Street fail to understand that it is a parody of those who will do anything to pursue wealth, when Gordon Gekko proclaims "greed is good" and pursues self enrichment to the max.

I'd like to update this mantra for our current crop of military hawks and opportunists : "Greed is good, disenfranchising the poor is better and ultimate power is the best".

You are wrong on four counts–impressive for a single sentence. First, your budget estimate is short three orders of magnitude.  Second, the scale of current budgets is not the problem, it is the imbalance between revenue and outlays.  Third, the imbalance was inherited from the previous administration's policy of tax cuts and warfare.  Fourth, maintaining both sides of this imbalance during the current administration has been the policy of an intransigent opposition party - using Senate cloture rules to prevent any vote allowing the Bush tax cuts (which had always been budgeted as temporary exactly because of their effect on long term fiscal outlook) and demagoguing any effort to rein in defense spending as unpatriotic.
What happened to our surpluses lives about nine miles north of me in a cul-de-sac guarded by the Secret Service.
I think you know what happened to those surpluses.

One way to visualize where the surpluses went is this:

http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2011/05/the-chart-that-shoul...

When Clinton was president he talked about making structural adjustments to get ready for the 21st century. When he left office, we had surpluses. If we still had them, we would be facing our problems instead of writing about them helplessly. What happened to our surpluses?

I would find your optimism more compelling were it not for the growing economic inequality in this country.  So long as wealth becomes more and more concentrated in the hands of a very small percentage of the population, demand will not be able to return.  In addition, the driving force of much wealth is to amass more wealth--there is little interest on the part of most rich people in projects which improve the quality of life for all our nation's citizens but do nothing for their pocketbooks.  The Depression brought an end to the last Gilded Age and taught some lessons that put some limits on how wealth could be amassed.  Unfortunately, this time, it doesn't seem like much has changed, with even suggestions of needed financial regulation and modest increased taxes for the wealthiest drawing screams of horror from Republican politicians who are then supported--thanks to the right-wing propaganda machine--by many of the very people being hurt by their policies.

They have declared the patient dead prematurely. Pessimism has become a national sport. We are still in our infancy, and the country has incredible growth ahead. Imagine going back to the mid 19th century and declaring the nations work completed. We are in a temporary slowdown, and that is all. Doom and gloom is nothing new, we have experienced it over and over, only to return to better times. There is nothing to suggest that this period is any different. Demand will return, as will home building and new infrastructure and new technologies. Twenty years from now, or even less, we could be entering an incredible period of new exploration into near space and then onto the moon. Anyone who thinks otherwise, will be proven very wrong.

The government can quickly and easily create hundreds of thousands, if not millions of jobs by providing extra assistance to state and local governments. The money would be used to hire back all the teachers and police officers and firefighters and municipal employees that have been laid off in recent years as local budgets have shrunk in the recession. (Most States and municipalities have balanced budget requirements that prevent them from counter-cyclical stimulus spending.) These re-hired teachers and firefighters would start spending more on food and clothing and cars and refrigerators and movie tickets and pedicures and ... (get the picture?) The companies that provide the pedicures and make the movies and sell the clothing would invest more in factories to make the clothes and stores to sell the pedicures and would hire more of your "laid off white collar workers" to manage the stores and the factories and the transportation networks required to get these goods and services to the newly re-employed teachers and firefighters and police officers. This is one example of 'what jobs the gov can create' for these laid off white collar workers.

The problem isn't a lack of capital available for businesses to expand. Companies are profitable and are sitting on huge piles of cash. They aren't investing in expanding their businesses because there aren't enough employed teachers and police officers and pedicurists and clothing store cashiers to buy their goods.

In order to achieve their "ideal" the Soviets sacrificed everyone and everything chasing a chimera.   To those in possession of "truth" no evidence to the contrary is accepted or acceptable and, like the Spanish Inquisition, they will burn all who oppose until nothing is left at all.  It is a matter of total indifference that people starve or die to the RepTbags and their supporters feel the same way just so long as it's not them that do the suffering.   The gulf between 1% thinking and 99% thinking is  unbridgeable.

I think Dr. Levine's comments here put too much blame on the parents, which is surprising, given what she said about the academic overload in schools in "The Race to Nowhere."

When schools pride themselves on how much homework they load their students up with (my daughter's high school proudly and repeatedly declares that their aim is for their students to have at least 3 hours of homework a night -- and we chose this school only because it was the least bad of a bad lot) and grade every little thing the kids do (whatever happened to mistakes being a part of the learning process?), telling them that those grades will determine whether they have a successful life or not (one of my daughter's teachers told the kids that if they didn't get top grades in high school, they'd end up being one of those people who hold signs up for businesses by the side of the road to catch the attention of passing motorists), then I think it's understandable that parents would try to protect their children from the damage that such a broken system inflicts.

What "they" are teaching is not irrevelant when what they are teaching your kid is that learning is a pointless and painful grind designed to make you feel miserable and exhausted and like you're always failing, with no end in sight: the race to nowhere that the documentary depicts.

Parents can't assume that their child will have a "successful failure" when the people at the other end, at the school, are so off-base about it.

You are blaming people who are only a very small part of the picture. The real problem is globalism and Free Trade. Multinational corporations are shipping factory jobs offshore, exploiting desperate, vulnerable people - paying them pennies an hour - and then turning around and bringing those goods back into our markets for free. These corporations have no alliegance to America or Americans or anyone other than themselves and their shareholders.

Americans need to face the fact that Free Trade isn't working out so well for most of us. Sure we gained a lot of cheap junk (that will end up in a land fill sooner than later) but we lost industries that contributed to our tax base as well as provided livelihoods. Most of the money those working class jobs created was spent in the local communities, thus creating more jobs.

You want your upward economic spiral? Dump Free Trade - It simply is not worth it.

Welfare -- it's great for banks and bad for people.  Yachts, private planes,  private dining rooms, 10-figure compensation packages to reward failure is "capitalism" today.  The con is that nothing is too big to fail only too big to exist.

Of course the problem is that we are asking the fox how to fix the henhouse. The answers that we are getting are not insincere. Those who are giving us those answers sincerely believe that they make sense and from a certain point of view it is so in that if the economy were not so out of whack those prescriptions would bring great prosperity and high earnings to those who are making them. But of course the economy is that out of whack and moreover when they are doing well it doesn't necessarily follow that everyone else is. In Buddhism the greatest sin is carelessness and that is their sin. It is not outright evil intentions, greed or malevolence that drives these idiocies but rather failure of imagination and intellectual laziness. It is in short carelessness and the Buddhists have it just right.

This is the fault of the Canadian parents, not the U.S. tax system.

I have, and continue to, run into absurdist regulations as an American businessman visiting Canada on a casual business basis, this for having ONCE worked on a business visa in Canada 20 years ago.

The Queen's colonies are far more bureaucratic than the U.S.

Diana,

Blaming education for not providing workers with the skills needed for industry and corporations is just an excuse. Corporate America has been itching for a reason to offshore jobs since the 80's and 90's. These companies don't want engineers; they want engineers they can pay $22,000 a year. They don't want machinists; they want machinists they can pay seventy five cents an hour.

The problem isn't that we aren't educating our kids, it is that we are educating them with the expectation they can expect a liveable wage.

The music stops??? The music is already stopped for a lot of people - that's what a depression is that's why you do a stimulus.

Can't afford it? We can't afford not to do a massive stimulus. The debt to GDP ratio at the end of WWII was 120% right now it's 80% - plenty of room there. The wealthy are currently taxed at historically low rates - they have to pay more, especially the financial geniuses who created this mess, so we need a financial transaction tax to compensate for the massive bail out that was required by the casino operators on Wall Street. We can afford the stimulus. We just have to make the people who made this mess (and in many cases profited from it) help pay for the fix.

Europe and Japan aren't decimated? Too bad. You haven't noticed that there are quite a few pre-decimated countries out there that could profit from a Marshall Plan type injection of capital to help jump start them into the modern world?

No, everything is not exactly like it was in 1939, so what? What did you do, stop thinking when you hung up your last diploma?

"Fatuous" comparisons to 1939? Here we sit, in a finance-induced recession with 0% bond rates and high unemployment, years after an anemic stimulus kept the bottom from dropping out but failed to fully restore the economy. Dr. K is suggesting that the open checkbook in the runup and for the duration of WWII ended the Great Depression, and unleashed a prosperity unparalleled in human existence once the war ended. I think he's right. I do NOT think he is proposing nuking France to repeat the glory. The France nukers are presently out of office, and I don't think Dr. K wants them back (jk :>). I think his point is that we need additional fiscal stimulus in 2012, just as we did in 1939, to finally put an end to a finance-induced economic catastrophe.

I hope your thesis adviser is a tough grader.

Vasthi4,

You don't have a clue what went on in the '50s, '60s, and '70s. In those days the U.S. exported food, oil, and Manafactured goods to the part of the world the Comunists didn't control. The country became wealthy doing it, today we can't even drill for oil to use domestically and building a road or putting up a new power line is a 10 year project. Does the phrase "not in my backyard", mean anything to you?

Oh, I so used to love Paul Krugman's columns. I must have been one of the few who paid when the Times first started charging for columnist columns, so I could read Paul and a choice few others.

But, now I see Krugman making fatuous comparisons between the current economic problems and 1939. So, I will point out the difference. In 1939, the government spent tons of money for a military buildup. A comparison to today we be for the government to spend a ton of money rebuilding (a plan I would be actually in favor of it I thought it would not wind up as pork and were we able to pay for it).

Unfortunately, as some point, the music stops. Then what? Well, back in 1945, Europe and Japan's structural capacity was DESTROYED. If you were living in the US, or Sweden and Switzerland, for that matter, you were sitting in the catbird seat. In other words, when the huge fiscal stimulus of war ended, we had factories and labor ready to go to produce not just for Americans craving consumer goods, but Europeans, as well.

How about now? Well, Japan and Europe are not leveled. So, after the music stop and the government pulls back on the fiscal strings, then what? Will we be selling much more to the Europeans and the Japanese? Doubtful. How about the tapped out American consumer, where the baby boom generation is entirely ill-prepared for retirement? I don't think so. So, when the music stops, we are left in the same hole we started in. It is structural.

Joel, Economics Ph.D. Econ Berkeley

What we have here is the confusion of economics with religion. Economic science requires proofs and experimentation. When a remedy is tried and it fails time and again, reasonable people conclude that remedy does not work. So now the cons want to change our system. What's wrong with the system is that it is clogged with radical, reactionary, Republicans.

The cons believe that the object of the economy is to make the rich richer still and they demand a greater share of the GDP. Millions beget millions more. The rich demand lower taxes so. others must surrender their safety nets. The people, kept ignorant and fearful shall provide labor as needed at whatever wages are offered. Any benefits only make the masses lazy. The Ryan budget in a nutshell.

However, if the purpose of the economy is to provide decent, secure employment for those who want to work and a strong government to provide funds for the mandate of the Constitution, in a democratic government, where all citizens are equal before the law, then you do what should be done; make the rich pay their fair share of taxes. I remember after Pearl Harbor there was a popular song which began: “We did it before and we can do it again....” Well the massive increase in government spending in the late 1930's jumped employment and created a surge in hiring and an upsurge in demand. People spent money. The people became job creators. But that was FDR and he was Satan. Doing what he did is against the religion of the cons.

I don't understand the structural unemployment arguement. OK, there may be, as always, pockets of real short term "shortage" in extreme high tech (e.g. Ph.D programmers), but most of the rest of the economy workers are fairly fungible in the medium term. How long does it take to train an oil industry entry level welder, maybe 4-6months. Finance workers? Most would be serviceable in many other general business management function. What counts is they are smart about the world, a spreadsheet at Goldman Sachs is a spreadsheet at Micosoft.

Because of decades of knowledge and innovation on how to parcel things out, most actual and potential jobs in the economy can be occupied (within weeks to months of training) by any existing workforce, distributed based on individual inherent level of education or main vocation.

Odd that the same set who propound strong form efficient markets appear to now back these structural arguements. If the markets are anywhere near efficient, they will pull surplus workers that are fungible in 1-2 years after a recession back to full employment. All this started in mid 2008 and we are still here.

This is not to say I fully agree with PK's ultimate prescription of the solution which can be boiled down, badly, as "more debt". I think spending on the right things can help, I also things structural reforms to make the markets more efficient and align incentives are in order, but everyone - yes that means yoy Jamie - want to protect their turf

He also states a "mass of confusion" accompanied the final days of MF Global's unwinding, and that no one knows what really happened. We already know this kind of characterization to be complete bunk! as senior MF executives have already taken the Fifth, and know exactly what happened. Other comments in these pages have also revealed the industry knows where the stolen money is. Interesting to see today's headline on JP Morgan's admission of a $2B loss due to idiocy. It's a wonder some of these people haven't been hunted down, and thrown in stocks by the People.

I'm not so sure we had that much individualism 2000 years ago. At that time most people were subordinates through slavery or their families. Women and children, especially, were regarded as property. It's not really that long ago that women and blacks received the vote.
Joe you have no idea what went on 2,000 years ago.

Truly democratic government is going to be the strongest asset of any successful economy from now on. Investments in science and education have nothing to do with private business, but will define the future of many nations. Common goals, common effort is the inspiration.

The end of US is written all over, particularly in the minds of her's citizenry. Individualism was good 2000 years ago, now alone you'll achieve very little, may be enough to die in peace.

For the second time in one day I have heard eminent professors state or directly imply that it takes the threat of war and death for our government to make decisions that make economic sense. This afternoon, Nielsen DeGrass Tyson spoke at the University of Wisconsin student union where he claimed the greatest technology strides came when the Congress feared the Soviet Union, such as our landing on the Moon. Paul Krugman rightly points out that once we committed to providing materials for WW I I that "structural" unemployment vanished. Are we such a weak culture that we can only make careful, risky decisions when threatened by war and death? It seems like it.

I remember way back when those Bush tax cuts were first passed. They were indeed touted as temporary cuts. Then, after more cuts were larded on top, eight years later the Republicans declared it was do or die in keeping them in place. They vowed nothing would happen unless they got to extend the cuts.

I have NEVER been able to figure out why Obama and company agreed to allow their continuance, other than inexperience and timidity in dealing with Congress. Of course, one doesn't want to raise taxes in a recession, but the funds could have been turned around immediately to stimulate the economy in a way that would be pegged closer to actual need than allow the money to sit in the bank accounts of the very wealthy. In fact, the govt. could have spent the money in a matter of months, waiting during the yr. for the added revenues to come in.

By giving in so quickly, instead of putting up a fight, Obama allowed the Republicans to get off too cheaply, without paying a price for their advocacy for the rich in a time of deep recession. This was a watershed moment in forming the shape and direction of this president's first term.

I don't disagree with Andrew here, but I do know what the percentage of laid off public employees is compared to the total of lost jobs. These are skilled people and making money available to local governments will certainly help, but I doubt ti will bring back several million lost home construction jobs. And a great majority of manufacturing jobs have been sent to countries where the labor force is far cheaper. I call this the Walmart effect. People are willing to give up quality for price. Just look up what happened to Rubbermaid when they tried to meet Walmart's demands for lower costs.

Go to any large US port and see what products are coming from Asia. Yes companies are sitting on large hordes of cash but these are not the mid size businesses that need to expand. How about Apple, how many more iPhones can they sell? Or Cisco, how many more servers are needed, or Kimberly Clark, are they going to ramp up toilet paper production?

Just the auto bailouts saved more jobs than all the public service people laid off. As I said above, look at what happened to the small towns in Washington state when the illegals were deported, and we are seeing the same happening in Alabama. these were the people who were buying the TVs, the pickups, the groceries, and these towns have lost 50% or more of their business in several cases.

Dr. Krugman, here is further evidence to support your case: If the structuralistas were correct, there would exist a class of goods and/or services where demand can't be satisfied due to a dearth of qualified workers. As a result prices of those goods would skyrocket, and the affected industry would have to pay to train people to fill these roles. I'm looking for examples of this phenomenon in our economy, and I cannot find any. I also can't find a case where those advancing the structural argument cite a single industry or product or service that suffers from this supposedly pervasive phenomenon.
